label: Columbia Records
location: Battery Studios in New York City
description: Wish You Were Here is the ninth studio album by the English rock band Pink Floyd, recorded 13 January – 28 July 1975 and released on 12 September 1975. The album's lyrical themes concern alienation and criticism of the music business. The bulk of the album is taken up by 'Shine On You Crazy Diamond', a nine-part tribute to founding member Syd Barrett, who left the band seven years earlier due to his deteriorating mental health.
tracks: Shine on You Crazy Diamond, Pts. 1-5
Shine on You Crazy Diamond, Pts. 6-9

label: Tarnia
location: Battery Studios in New York City
description: What's Going On is the eleventh studio album by American soul singer Marvin Gaye. It was released on May 21, 1971. What's Going On is a concept album with most of its songs segueing into the next and has been categorized as a song cycle. The narrative established by the songs is told from the point of view of a Vietnam veteran returning to his home country to witness hatred, suffering, and injustice.

label: Motown
location: Battery Studios in New York City
description: Mama's Gun is the second studio album by American singer Erykah Badu. It was recorded between 1999 and 2000 at Electric Lady Studios in New York and released on November 21, 2000. A neo soul album, Mama's Gun incorporates elements of funk, soul, and jazz styles.[2] It has confessional lyrics by Badu, which cover themes of insecurity, personal relationships, and social issues.A neo soul album, Mama's Gun incorporates elements of funk, soul, and jazz styles.[2] It has confessional lyrics by Badu, which cover themes of insecurity, personal relationships, and social issues.

label: TDE
location: Battery Studios in New York City
description: To Pimp a Butterfly is the third studio album by American rapper Kendrick Lamar. It was released on March 15, 2015. Primarily a hip hop album, To Pimp a Butterfly incorporates numerous other musical styles spanning the history of African-American music, most prominently jazz, funk, and soul. Lyrically, it features political commentary and personal themes concerning African-American culture, racial inequality, depression, and institutional discrimination. This thematic direction was inspired by Lamar's tour of historic sites during his visit to South Africa, such as Nelson Mandela's jail cell on Robben Island.

label: Virgin
description: Voodoo is the second studio album by American singer, songwriter, and multi-instrumentalist D'Angelo, released on January 25, 2000. Produced primarily by the singer, Voodoo features a loose, groove-based funk sound and serves as a departure from the more conventional song structure of his debut album, Brown Sugar (1995). Its lyrics explore themes of spirituality, love, sexuality, maturation, and fatherhood.

label: PMR
description: Settle is the debut studio album by English electronic music duo Disclosure, released on June 3, 2013. The brothers behind Disclosure, Howard and Guy Lawrence, seem impossibly young considering their talents: Guy is 21, while younger brother Howard just turned 18 a few weeks ago. But they've actually been on the scene for three years, and their artistic growth over that period is impressive.
tracks: When A Fire Starts To Burn

label: Parlophone/Capitol
description: OK Computer is the third studio album by the English rock band Radiohead, released in the UK on 16 June 1997. They distanced themselves from the guitar-centred, lyrically introspective style of their previous album, The Bends. OK Computer's abstract lyrics, densely layered sound and eclectic influences laid the groundwork for Radiohead's later, more experimental work.

label: Jive
location: Battery Studios in New York City
description: Midnight Marauders is the third studio album by American hip hop group A Tribe Called Quest, released on November 9, 1993. A culmination of the group's two previous albums, People's Instinctive Travels and the Paths of Rhythm and The Low End Theory, it features an eclectic, gritty sound based on jazz, funk, soul and R&B samples, in addition to socially conscious, positively-minded, and humorous lyrics.

label: XL
description: The Fat of the Land is the third studio album by English electronic music group the Prodigy, released on 30 June 1997. While Liam Howlett is generally responsible for the compositions and Maxim Reality is featured on two tracks, this is the first record to include contributions by Keith Flint. The Fat of the Land album cover featured an image of a halloween moon crab[8] and a new logo, dropping 'The' and adding an ant silhouette. The album title comes from the old English phrase 'living off the fat of the land', which means living well or being wealthy

label: Epic
description: Rage Against the Machine is the debut studio album by American rock band Rage Against the Machine. With politically themed, revolutionary lyrical content, the album artwork was notable for featuring a graphic photograph of Thích Quảng Đức performing self-immolation. Coincidentally, the release date for Rage Against the Machine was on November 3, 1992, the same day as the 1992 United States presidential election.

label: Columbia
description: Kind of Blue is the fifth studio album released on Columbia, and twenty-eighth overall, by American jazz musician, trumpeter, composer, and bandleader Miles Davis. For the recording, Davis led a sextet featuring saxophonists John Coltrane and Julian 'Cannonball' Adderley, pianist Bill Evans, bassist Paul Chambers, and drummer Jimmy Cobb, with new band pianist Wynton Kelly appearing on one track – 'Freddie Freeloader' – in place of Evans.

producers: Rick Rubin, Daron Malakian, Serj Tankian
label: Columbia, American
description: Toxicity is the second studio album by the American heavy metal band System of a Down, released on September 4, 2001. Toxicity incorporates more melody, harmonies, and singing than the band's first album. Categorized primarily as alternative metal and nu metal, the album features elements of multiple genres, including folk, progressive rock, jazz, and Armenian and Greek music, including prominent use of instruments like the sitar, banjo, keyboards, and piano.

label: Janus Records
description: Cymande (pronounced /sɪˈmɑːndeɪ/ sih-MAHN-day) is the debut album by British funk group Cymande. It was released in 1972 through Janus Records and produced entirely by John Schroeder. Recording sessions took place at De Lane Lea Studios in London. The album peaked at No. 85 on the Billboard Top LPs and No. 24 on the Soul Albums in the United States. It spawned two singles, 'The Message' and 'Bra', both made it to the Soul Singles chart, reaching No. 22 and No. 51 respectively. Its lead single 'The Message' also peaked at No. 48 on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart.

label: Noo Trybe, Virgin
description: Moment of Truth is the fifth studio album by American hip hop duo Gang Starr, DJ Premier and Guru released on March 31, 1998, by Noo Trybe Records and Virgin Records. DJ Premier, the groups MC/DJ produced the album with Guru (Gifted Unlimited Rhymes Universal), who is the rapper of the group. Gang Starr recorded Moment of Truth in sessions at D&D Studios. It is widely regarded as Gang Starr's magnum opus, and one of the greatest hip hop albums of all time aswell as the best Rap/DJ duo of all time.

albumTitle: Songs in the Key of Life
label: Tarnia
description: Songs in the Key of Life is the eighteenth studio album by American singer, songwriter and musician Stevie Wonder. A double album, it was released on September 28, 1976. It was recorded primarily at Crystal Sound studio in Hollywood, with some sessions recorded at the Record Plant in Hollywood, the Record Plant in Sausalito, and The Hit Factory in New York City; final mixing was conducted at Crystal Sound.[6] The album has been regarded by music journalists as the culmination of Wonder's 'classic period' of recording.
tracks: Love's in Need of Love Today
Ngiculela -- Es Una Historia -- I Am Singing

label: Vertigo, Warner Bros.
description: Paranoid is the second studio album by English heavy metal band Black Sabbath, released on 18 September 1970. The album contains several of the band's signature songs, including 'Iron Man', 'War Pigs' and the title track, which was the band's only Top 20 hit, reaching number 4 on the UK charts. Paranoid is widely regarded as one of the greatest and most influential heavy metal albums of all time, often cited as a key influence for the development of the genre as well as one of its earliest albums.
members: Ozzy Ozbourne, Tony Iommi, Geezer Butler, Bill Ward

label: Virgin, Circa
description: Mezzanine is the third studio album by English electronic music group Massive Attack, released on 20 April 1998 by Circa and Virgin Records. For the album, the group began to explore a darker aesthetic, and focused on a more atmospheric style influenced by British post-punk, industrial music, hip hop and dub music. Mezzanine was conceptualized by lead Massive Attack member Robert Del Naja in 1997, who wanted to focus on exploring a darker audiovisual aesthetic with distinct influences. The production of the album was a stressful process; with tensions arising, it led to disagreements that almost split the group, including discouragement from Andrew Vowles.
members: Robert Del Naja, Adrain Thaws, Grant Marshall

label: Gol Beat, London
description: Dummy is the debut studio album by English electronic music band Portishead, released on 22 August 1994. The production of the album uses a number of hip-hop techniques, such as sampling, scratching, and loop-making.[8] The album was not recorded digitally. They sampled music from other records, but they also recorded their own original music, which was then recorded onto vinyl records before manipulating them on record decks to sample.
members: Beth Gibbons, Geoff Barrow, Adrian Utley

label: Gol Beat, London
description: Late Registration is the second studio album by American rapper and producer Kanye West. It was released on August 30, 2005. West's production for Late Registration departed from the sped-up soul samples of his debut studio album, The College Dropout (2004), moving towards a more elaborate and orchestral style with a 20-piece ensemble. In an effort to write authentic yet relatable lyrics, West engages in storytelling while showcasing his Christian heritage that informed his relationship to the capitalist market economy. He critiques multiple issues, such as institutional racism, higher education, health care, and the blood diamond trade.
